caption.text: Classification of the Krylov subspace methods.

cell.text: Shifted conjugate gradient (CG) method (using real vector)
Shifted conjugate gradient (CG) method (using complex vector)
Shifted conjugate orthogonal conjugate gradient (COCG) method

statement.text: Krylov subspace methods have been classified into 44 types.
The solver name is different for all 44 types.
Type of A + E I has only Real symmetric, Hermitian and Complex symmetric .
The Otherwise type has Shifted conjugate gradient (CG) method (using complex vector) as the method.
Shifted conjugate orthogonal conjugate gradient (COCG) method is a method used for Hermitian .
Krylov subspace methods have been classified into 4 types.
All four solver names are unique.
Real symmetric ,Hermitian , Complex symmetric and Otherwise are all types of A + E I.
The Hermitian type has Shifted conjugate gradient (CG) method (using complex vector) as the method.
Shifted conjugate orthogonal conjugate gradient (COCG) method is a method used for Complex symmetric .
An appropriate solver should be selected depending on whether the type of Hamiltonian H and the frequency z are complex or real, as shown in Table 1 .
It is noted that H must be Hermitian or symmetric for a complex or real matrix, respectively.
For an efficient calculation, the seed switching function [7] is introduced in all methods.

statement.text: There are 8 E n values in the given table.
The SS(10,1) is available for both 5 E n and 6 E n.
The highest H value is -4.297689 at E n=0 ,
The SS(10,2) values are not the same as the SS(10,5) values.
The lowest SS(10,1) value is -4.777389 for E n =4.
There are 7 E n values in the given table.
The SS(10,1) is NA for both 5 E n and 6 E n.
The highest H value is -5.387391 for E n =0.
The SS(10,2) values are same as the SS(10,5) values.
The lowest SS(10,1) value is -4.297689 for E n =4.
To see the convergence of the contour-integral method, we show the obtained eigenvalues for several different conditions.
By taking about 50 different bases, we can obtain the correct eigenvalues including degeneracies.

caption.text: The operational costs per iteration are listed for (i) the conventional Krylov method, (ii) the shifted Krylov subspace method for the whole elements of the solution vectors, and (iii) the shifted Krylov subspace method for the projection of the solution vectors . The operational costs of the sparse matrix–vector products (SpMV), the scalar–vector products (SV), and the inner products (Inner) are listed separately.

statement.text: The inner products (Inner) for Shift (whole) method is unique.
There are three methods in the table.
The inner products (Inner) are 3 M N eq AND 3 M
The Shift (projection) of SV is partially 3 M + 3 M left.
As an advantage of the present method, it meets the demand for extremely large problems, such as quantum lattice models with matrix size
